title: U.S. shouldn’t deal with threats alone
text:
Part of what has made America great throughout the years is our standing at the ready to help defend freedom against rogue nations, and to stand up against global injustice and tyranny.

Iran has consistently been a rogue nation, especially the past 40 years or so, tied to a radical belief system and having a hand in war, mayhem and instability in the Persian Gulf. They’ve hardly been a friend to U.S. interests or our allies in the region.

After a drone attack on a Saudi Arabian oil field and processing facility last weekend, Houthi rebels in Yemen claimed responsibility. The strike badly damaged the facility, threatening the world’s oil supply and scrambling international financial markets.

Yemen, a 99% Muslim nation of more than 28 million people, has for five years been in a tug-of-war between its Saudi-supported government, southern separatists backed by the United Arab Emirates, and the Houthi rebels who are being supplied by Iran. The U.N. recognizes Saudi’s horse as the legitimate government. The UAE position supports a division of the country between what was, until 1990, North Yemen and South Yemen. Unification hasn’t taken, and the Houthis are agents of chaos; they feel unrepresented by the goings-on and have taken to terrorism within Yemen to express their dismay.

The Saudis are leery of an expanded Iranian influence gaining stronger footing in its southern neighbor. The UAE seems to have concluded that this is a losing proposition, and has been cutting its losses via reduced engagement. The entire situation is causing strain between Saudi Arabia and the UAE, other members of the Arab world, and in Washington, which prefers to have stable relationships with both kingdoms but let’s be frank: Saudi Arabia has always been seen as more important to American interests, and the sitting president’s long-standing relationship with the Saudis only adds another wrinkle to the problems.

The drone attack only makes things worse. The Houthis are tenacious pests, but universally seen as unlikely to have the capability to launch a sophisticated attack such as was undertaken last week. The international community seems unified in seeing Persian fingerprints on this incident.

But at a time of great tension, rhetoric such as that offered by Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, who called the attacks an “act of war,” is a little scary. To the Saudis, perhaps. To America? Please tap the brakes a bit, Mr. Secretary.

Instability in the region is a given … we’re not the world’s cop, and should be very deliberate before committing American might and military to a widening conflict … something that would incite a part of the world that already hates us. If it’s proven that Iran was behind this, there are some steps we can take before it escalates into full-on warfare.

It seems clear Iran can’t be trusted, but this is not the time to shoot first and ask questions later. America is no longer as reliant on oil from the Middle East or Southwest Asia as it once was … but China is, as are numerous other countries much closer to the conflict. Before we go charging in, maybe the Chinese or the Russians or the Israelis can handle the trouble in their own backyard first.

President Trump has hinted at action against Iran, but been remarkably measured in avoiding any sort of knee-jerk response that would rope us into war or near-war. That’s to his credit.

The United States is more than ready to join a coalition of nations set to beat back global threats, but we shouldn’t go it alone.
